00019 /**
00020 
00021 @page fdo Profile-feedback optimization
00022 
00023 @section fdo_intro 1. Introduction
00024 
00025   Profile-feedback optimization also known as feedback-driven
00026   optimization (FDO) can significantly improve the compiler's decision
00027   on what optimizations would be beneficial in which parts of the
00028   program.  On many applications, we have measured 15-20% improvement
00029   due to this optimization.
00030 
00031   To provide the profile information to the compiler initially a
00032   so-called training run is performed with an instrumented version of
00033   the program.  In the second pass the profile data produced in the
00034   training run is consulted by the compiler during the various
00035   optimizations it performs.
00036 
00037   The Simple Executive does not provide a file system where normally
00038   the profile data is saved.  We provide different solutions to gather
00039   profile data on the simulator and on the hardware.
00040 
00041   Profile data is emitted when the program exits.  For programs that never
00042   exit, the bootloader provides a way to force an exit.
00043 
00044   @note The program used to produce the profile data has to be
00045   essentially identical to the program compiled in the second pass.
00046   If there is a change in a structural in the program, the second pass
00047   will refuse to accept the profile data file with messages like:
00048 
00049 @verbatim
00050   /tmp/a.c:2: error: coverage mismatch for function 'main' while reading counter 'arcs'
00051   /tmp/a.c:2: error: checksum is 1f18b8db instead of 112c2d5e
00052 @endverbatim
00053 
00054   @note When compiling the second pass GCC only issues a note if the
00055   profile data file cannot be found.  For example
00056 
00057 @verbatim
00058   executive/cvmx-zone.c:164: note: file obj-octeon/cvmx-zone.gcda not found, execution counts estimated
00059 @endverbatim
00060 
00061   It is expected that if an object file is included in an archive but
00062   never actually becomes part of the link there will be no profile
00063   data generated for it.  In other cases this note probably means that
00064   GCC was not looking at the place where you put the profile data (see
00065   \ref fdo_multicore how this can happen) or the training run has
00066   failed to produce profiling output because perhaps the program did
00067   not exit normally.
00068 
00069     The rest of the page describes various issues in more details:
00070 
00071     - @ref fdo_multicore
00072     - @ref fdo_pass1
00073     - @ref fdo_break
00074     - @ref fdo_sim
00075     - @ref fdo_serial
00076     - @ref fdo_pass2
00077     - @ref fdo_merge
00078     - @ref fdo_display
00079 
00080 @section fdo_multicore 2. Core-specific profile data
00081 
00082   Given the multi-core nature of OCTEON profile data is always core
00083   specific.  The compiler run-time has been modified to output profile
00084   data for each core.  The core number will be attached to the file
00085   name of the profile data file.  E.g. the profile data for the module
00086   foo.c produced on core 3 will be named foo.gcda3.
00087 
00088   Before compiling in the second pass you need to provide a .gcda file
00089   for each module.  This is the file that will be used by the
00090   compiler.  You can either rename per-code data files to end with
00091   .gcda or you can merge the per-core files.  Read on for examples on
00092   both of these.
00093 
00094 @section fdo_pass1 3. Building for training (1st) phase
00095 
00096   The SDK build system provides a makefile variable @b FDO_PASS to activate
00097   profile-feedback compilation.  This can be most simply passed on the make
00098   command line.  If the variable is set to 1, @b -fprofile-generate is passed
00099   to the compiler which will turn on instrumentation.  If the variable is set
00100   to 2, @b -fprofile-use is passed in which case GCC will look for the profile
00101   data files (*.gcda).
00102 
00103   For example to build the SDK example passthrough to perform a training run
00104   use these steps:
00105 
00106 @verbatim
00107   examples/passthrough$ make -s clean
00108   examples/passthrough$ make FDO_PASS=1 OCTEON_USE_LOCAL_LIB=1
00109   cvmx-config config/executive-config.h
00110   mipsisa64-octeon-elf-gcc -fprofile-generate -g -O2 -c -o obj-octeon/passthrough.o passthrough.c ...
00111 ...
00112 @endverbatim
00113 
00114 @section fdo_sim 4. Collecting profile data using the OCTEON simulator
00115 
00116   The OCTEON simulator maps I/O operations to the appropriate I/O
00117   operation of the host system (see \ref magic).  Thus the profile
00118   data generated by the GCC run-time will appear as regular files on
00119   the host system.
00120 
00121   For example to run the SDK example passthrough to generate profile data
00122   perform these steps:
00123 
00124 @verbatim
00125   examples/passthrough$ make FDO_PASS=1 OCTEON_USE_LOCAL_LIB=1 run
00126   oct-packet-io -p 2000 -c 1 -o output-%d.data -i input-0.data -i input-1.data -i input-2.data -i input-3.data &
00127   oct-sim passthrough -quiet -serve=2000 -maxcycles=120000000 -numcores=4
00128   Starting simulator....
00129 ...
00130 @endverbatim
00131 
00132   At this point the per-core profile data files will be under obj-octeon/.
00133   You can rebuild the application using profile data, see @ref
00134   fdo_pass2.
00135 
00136 @section fdo_break 5. Forcing programs to exit
00137 
00138 Profile data is only written to the console at exit time through and
00139 atexit() handler.  There are some programs that run forever and never
00140 call exit() or return from main() programmatically.  To help to
00141 collect profile data for such applications we provide an option @b
00142 break to the boot command @b bootoct which forces the program to exit
00143 upon receiving a ctrl-c character on the console.
00144 
00145 @note On the simulator, in order to pass @b break to @b bootoct you need to
00146 use the @b -envfile simulator option (see @ref oct-sim).  You also need to use
00147 @b -uart0/-uart1 option (@ref sim_args) to issue ctrl-c on the console.  With
00148 most telnet clients ctrl-c is associated with the protocol command interrupt.
00149 You need to disable that so that ctrl-c is passed to the serial port
00150 unchanged:
00151 
00152 @verbatim
00153   $ telnet localhost 1234
00154   Trying 127.0.0.1...
00155   Connected to localhost.localdomain.
00156   Escape character is '^]'.
00157 
00158 
00159   U-Boot 1.1.1 (U-boot build #: 189) (SDK version: 1.7.3-257) (Build time: May 22
00160   2008 - 21:00:00)
00161 ...
00162 
00163   ^]
00164   telnet> unset interrupt
00165   interrupt character is 'off'.
00166   ^C
00167 @endverbatim
00168 
00169 ^] stands for the escape character to enter command mode.  After hitting
00170 ctrl-c you might need to hit an enter as well to flush out the ctrl-c in line
00171 mode.
00172 
00173 @section fdo_serial 6. Collecting profile data on the hardware through the serial console.
00174 
00175 The Simple Executive environment does not provide a file system.  To
00176 collect profile data we extended newlib (libc) to provide a very
00177 simple write-only memory based file system.  A few low level file I/O
00178 operations (open, write, close) maintain the contents of the files in
00179 memory.  Upon exit the contents of the files are dumped on the console
00180 uuencoded.
00181 
00182 The memory used for the files is allocated from the heap.  In case the
00183 heap is exhausted while trying to write profile data, you should see
00184 the following messages:
00185 
00186 @verbatim
00187   memfile: out of memory
00188 @endverbatim
00189 
00190 If necessary you can increase the heap size when booting (see \ref
00191 bootloader).
00192 
00193 You should capture the console output in the profile run and then run
00194 @b oct-uudecode on the resulting file.  The tool @b oct-uudecode
00195 unlike the standard uudecode tool can decode multiple files.
00196 
00197 Here is a sample session using @b break option with the SDK example
00198 passthrough:
00199 
00200 @verbatim
00201   $ kermit
00202   C-Kermit 8.0.211, 10 Apr 2004, for Linux
00203    Copyright (C) 1985, 2004,
00204     Trustees of Columbia University in the City of New York.
00205   Type ? or HELP for help.
00206 
00207   C-Kermit>send log session session.log
00208 
00209   C-Kermit>c
00210 
00211   Connecting to /dev/ttyUSB0, speed 115200
00212    Escape character: Ctrl-\ (ASCII 28, FS): enabled
00213   Type the escape character followed by C to get back,
00214   or followed by ? to see other options.
00215   Session Log: session.log, text
00216   ----------------------------------------------------
00217 
00218   Octeon ebt3000# bootoct 0x100000 coremask=ffff break
00219   Bootloader: Booting Octeon Executive application at 0x00100000, core mask: 0xffff, stack size: 0x100000, heap size: 0x300000
00220   Bootloader: Done loading app on coremask: 0xffff
00221   PP0:~CONSOLE-> Version: Cavium Inc. Octeon SDK version 1.6.0, build 193
00222   PP0:~CONSOLE-> Port 16: Up     1Gbs Full duplex
00223   PP0:~CONSOLE-> Port 17: Down   1Gbs Half duplex
00224   PP0:~CONSOLE-> Port 18: Down   1Gbs Half duplex
00225   PP0:~CONSOLE-> Port 19: Down   1Gbs Half duplex
00226   PP0:~CONSOLE-> Disabling backpressure
00227 @endverbatim
00228 
00229 In this example we train with the traffic generator.  After generating
00230 enough traffic we force the program to exit by hitting control-C on
00231 the console.
00232 
00233 @note Since the break handler will need to write to the console,
00234 breaks will be ignored unless the the handler was able to secure
00235 access to the console.  If the application is using the console
00236 extensively, it make take hitting control-c a few time before the
00237 dumping would start:
00238 
00239 @verbatim
00240   PP0:~CONSOLE-> Disabling backpressure
00241 
00242   ^C
00243 
00244   Dumping files on core 0
00245   begin 644 examples/passthrough/obj-octeon/passthrough.gcda0
00246   M9V-D830P,2KFX&JS 0        (   "H3^8_ @&A      !8     0
00247   M   !          $                    !          $          0
00248 
00249 ...
00250 
00251   begin 644 examples/passthrough/obj-octeon/octeon-model.gcda13
00252   M9V-D830P,2KFX*(: 0        (    ND,M)Y &A       H
00253   M
00254   M
00255   M
00256   M                      $        "    &Q%MCS(!H0       @
00257   M    H0        D         %0    $
00258   M  "C        "22];ZT   97     0-*/+$      (//Z@      @\_J
00259   %
00260   `
00261   end
00262   Done dumping files on core 13
00263 @endverbatim
00264 
00265 @note Cores can dump their profile data in any order.  Make sure all
00266 have finished before you proceed to the next step.
00267 
00268 Now you can extract the files using @b oct-uudecode.
00269 
00270 @verbatim
00271   C-Kermit>q
00272   Closing /dev/ttyUSB0...OK
00273 
00274   $ oct-uudecode session.log
00275   examples/passthrough/obj-octeon/passthrough.gcda0
00276   examples/passthrough/obj-octeon/cvmx-fpa.gcda0
00277   examples/passthrough/obj-octeon/cvmx-pko.gcda0
00278   examples/passthrough/obj-octeon/cvmx-sysinfo.gcda0
00279   examples/passthrough/obj-octeon/cvmx-coremask.gcda0
00280 
00281 ...
00282 
00283   examples/passthrough/obj-octeon/cvmx-ebt3000.gcda13
00284   examples/passthrough/obj-octeon/octeon-model.gcda13
00285   examples/passthrough/obj-octeon/cvmx-interrupt.gcda13
00286   $
00287 @endverbatim
00288 
00289 At this point per-core profile data files are under
00290 examples/passthrough/obj-octeon.
00291 
00292 @section fdo_pass2 7. Rebuilding the application using profile data.
00293 
00294   We pick core zero for the profile data and rename the files for
00295   core0 to end with .gcda.
00296 
00297   Here we assumed that core0 was representative of the whole
00298   application.  You can also merge all or specific per-core profile
00299   data files or you can merge profile data from different runs, see
00300   @ref fdo_merge.
00301 
00302 @verbatim
00303   examples/passthrough$ for i in obj-octeon/*.gcda0; do cp $i ${i%0}; done
00304 
00305   examples/passthrough$ make OCTEON_USE_LOCAL_LIB=1 -s clean cvmx-lib-clean  # preserves .gcda files
00306 
00307   examples/passthrough$ make FDO_PASS=2 OCTEON_USE_LOCAL_LIB=1  run
00308   cvmx-config config/executive-config.h
00309   mipsisa64-octeon-elf-gcc -fprofile-use -g -O2 -c -o obj-octeon/passthrough.o passthrough.c ...
00310 
00311 ...
00312 @endverbatim
00313 
00314 @section fdo_merge 8. Merging profile data
00315 
00316 You can merge profile data generated for different cores or across
00317 different executions of the program.  This enables incrementally
00318 training the program based on the different run-time conditions.
00319 
00320 The merging tool is called @b merge-gcda:
00321 
00322 @verbatim
00323 $ mipsisa64-octeon-elf-merge-gcda --help
00324 Usage: mipsisa64-octeon-elf-merge-gcda <option(s)> <files>
00325     or mipsisa64-octeon-elf-merge-gcda <option(s)> <directories>
00326     or mipsisa64-octeon-elf-merge-gcda <option(s)>
00327 
00328  Merge GCC profile output files.
00329 
00330  In the first variant <file(s)> are merged into a single output file.  By
00331  default the output filename is derived from the first file name by
00332  removing the trailing numeric characters.
00333  In the second variant, files with the identical names from <directories>
00334  are merged into files with the same name under the current directory.
00335  If neither <files> nor <directories> are specified each
00336  <module>.gcda{0..15} file in the current directory is merged into a
00337  <module>.gcda file.
00338 
00339  Possible <option(s)> are:
00340   -o, --output=<output>  When outputting a single file (first variant) this
00341                          store the merged data in this file.  When
00342                          generating multiple files (first and second
00343                          variant), store the files under this directory.
00344   -f, --factors=f1:f2:.. When merging, weigh the first input file
00345                          with integer factor f1, second with f2, etc
00346   -h, --help             Display help message
00347 @endverbatim
00348 
00349 Assuming you have the profile data files for each module generated for
00350 each core in the current directory you can merge them per module by
00351 executing @b merge-gcda with no arguments.  Assuming the passthrough
00352 example from above:
00353 
00354 @verbatim
00355   examples/passthrough$ cd obj
00356   examples/passthrough/obj$ mipsisa64-octeon-elf-merge-gcda
00357   Merging these files into cvmx-app-init.gcda:
00358     cvmx-app-init.gcda0
00359     cvmx-app-init.gcda1
00360     cvmx-app-init.gcda10
00361     cvmx-app-init.gcda11
00362     cvmx-app-init.gcda12
00363     cvmx-app-init.gcda13
00364     cvmx-app-init.gcda14
00365     cvmx-app-init.gcda15
00366     cvmx-app-init.gcda2
00367     cvmx-app-init.gcda3
00368     cvmx-app-init.gcda4
00369     cvmx-app-init.gcda5
00370     cvmx-app-init.gcda6
00371     cvmx-app-init.gcda7
00372     cvmx-app-init.gcda8
00373     cvmx-app-init.gcda9
00374   Merging these files into cvmx-bootmem-shared.gcda:
00375     cvmx-bootmem-shared.gcda0
00376     cvmx-bootmem-shared.gcda1
00377     cvmx-bootmem-shared.gcda10
00378     cvmx-bootmem-shared.gcda11
00379 
00380 ...
00381 @endverbatim
00382 
00383 You can also merge profile data across different runs.  Assuming that
00384 you have profile data for two runs in directory run1 and run2 you can
00385 merge them by passing the directories to @b merge-gcda:
00386 
00387 @verbatim
00388   examples/passthrough/obj$ mipsisa64-octeon-elf-merge-gcda ../run1 ../run2
00389   Merging these files into cvmx-app-init.gcda:
00390     ../run1/cvmx-app-init.gcda
00391     ../run2/cvmx-app-init.gcda
00392   Merging these files into cvmx-bootmem-shared.gcda:
00393     ../run1/cvmx-bootmem-shared.gcda
00394     ../run2/cvmx-bootmem-shared.gcda
00395 
00396 ...
00397 @endverbatim:
00398 
00399 @section fdo_display 9. Displaying profile data
00400 
00401   The tool @b gcov can be used to display some aspects of the profile
00402   data collected.  @b gcov is used to analyze the profile output in
00403   terms of coverage so the format of the output will only cover this
00404   part of the information and will only show how many times each
00405   source line was executed and point out the lines that had no
00406   coverage.
00407 
00408   For example invoke @b gcov to display the profile data for
00409   passthrough's main module from the previous section:
00410 
00411 @verbatim
00412   examples/passthrough$ mipsisa64-octeon-elf-gcov -o obj-octeon passthrough.c
00413   File 'passthrough.c'
00414   Lines executed:77.17% of 127
00415   passthrough.c:creating 'passthrough.c.gcov'
00416 
00417 ...
00418 
00419   examples/passthrough$ cat passthrough.c.gcov
00420      -:    0:Source:passthrough.c
00421      -:    0:Graph:obj-octeon/passthrough.gcno
00422      -:    0:Data:obj-octeon/passthrough.gcda
00423      -:    0:Runs:1
00424      -:    0:Programs:1
00425      -:    1:/****************************************************************
00426      -:    2: * Copyright (c) 2003-2005, Cavium Inc.. All rights reserved.
00427 
00428 ...
00429 
00430      -:  159:static void application_main_loop(void)
00431      1:  160:{
00432      -:  161:    cvmx_wqe_t *    work;
00433      -:  162:    uint64_t        port;
00434      -:  163:    cvmx_buf_ptr_t  packet_ptr;
00435      -:  164:    cvmx_pko_command_word0_t pko_command;
00436      -:  165:
00437      -:  166:
00438      -:  167:    /* Build a PKO pointer to this packet * /
00439      1:  168:    pko_command.u64 = 0;
00440      1:  169:    if (cvmx_sysinfo_get()->board_type == CVMX_BOARD_TYPE_SIM)
00441      -:  170: {
00442      1:  171:       pko_command.s.size0 = CVMX_FAU_OP_SIZE_64;
00443      1:  172:       pko_command.s.subone0 = 1;
00444      1:  173:       pko_command.s.reg0 = FAU_OUTSTANDING;
00445      -:  174: }
00446      -:  175:
00447      -:  176:    while (1)
00448      -:  177: {
00449      -:  178:
00450      -:  179:        /* get the next packet/work to process from the POW unit. * /
00451   1518:  180:        if (cvmx_sysinfo_get()->board_type == CVMX_BOARD_SIM_TYPE)
00452      -:  181: {
00453   1518:  182:           work = cvmx_pow_work_request_sync(CVMX_POW_NO_WAIT);
00454   1518:  183:           if (work == NULL) {
00455 
00456 ...
00457 @endverbatim
00458 
00459 The header contains the number of runs which tells how many runs you
00460 have merged into this profile data file.
00461 
00462 */
